instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no power. The ampmeter doesn't even power on, so the mac doesn't pull any voltage

 <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> it's not shorted - 1k ohm 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 13 k ohm
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 8 M ohm
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 18 k ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.2 k ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 150 ohm

It had the DB500 broken, and I have already replaced (with the same result).
I can't see any oxidation, and don't have any history of it.
Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground for all CC1/2 pins of USB-C ports.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
Sorry, but i can't figure it out where I can measure CC1/2 pins.
Are they <SIGNAL>USBC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_CC1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USBC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_CC2</SIGNAL> and can they be measured on the capacitators?
Can you please specify them?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
HI,

J3300
PIN 3 (<SIGNAL>XB_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.590V
PIN 53 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.203V
PIN 6 (<SIGNAL>XB_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.510V
PIN 52 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.580V

JB500
PIN 52 (<SIGNAL>TA_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.616V
PIN 6 (<SIGNAL>TB_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.625V
PIN 3 (<SIGNAL>TB_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.622V
PIN 53 (<SIGNAL>TA_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.617V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"PIN 53 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.203V"
This looks bad.
Check the components connected there.
Possibly bad <CAPACITOR>C3215</CAPACITOR> chip.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
The cd3215C had a small burnt hole... I replaced and the short is gone, but still no power, and ampmeter powerd off.
PIN 53 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.600V and 12M ohm
Also the <DIODE>D3328</DIODE> was broken and i replaced it. However i have 0V on diode mode and 100 M ohm of resistance in the pin 31 of the J3300

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Still black meter, not 5V?
Check <SIGNAL>XB_CC2</SIGNAL> too; had low value before.
In fact this <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> pair has all values lower than other pair.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
The amp meter is fully black. (now it tries to start, but immediately goes fully black. Very,very quickly almost not noted)). Previously, it was always full black).
PIN 3 (<SIGNAL>XB_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.600V
PIN 53 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.617V
PIN 6 (<SIGNAL>XB_CC2</SIGNAL>) = 0.510V
PIN 52 (<SIGNAL>XA_CC1</SIGNAL>) = 0.580V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>XB_CC2</SIGNAL> is still too low, comparing with the other lines.
Check diode protection, or corresponding <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Sorry, but I didn't understood what you meant by " Check diode protection, or corresponding <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip ". <CAPACITOR>C3214</CAPACITOR> and DZ3351 seems to be ok. Shell I replace this <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> seems to be shorted. On it i get 0.13 ohm of resistance and 0.0002mV on diode mode, and the <DIODE>D3370</DIODE> seems to be a little decolourized (not sure).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R3370</RESISTOR> and check if short gone.
First remove USB-C connectors from shell and clean the pins.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I can't find the  <RESISTOR>R3370</RESISTOR>  on my schematics. Are you sure this is the one?
Already clean the pins, and i'm testing without the  connectors  but same result

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Sorry, <DIODE>D3370</DIODE>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I lifted up <DIODE>D3370</DIODE> and the pad was gone (burnt). The short disapered and so i made a jumper from <CAPACITOR>C3354</CAPACITOR> pad, and solder the diode back again. The short is gone, but still no power (black meter)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Do you get any voltage at F3000/1?
If not, then change <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I don't get any voltages on F3000/1, but something funny happens:
On one of the ports of J3300, if I flip the meter, the meter works and the mac puls 4.97V, and consumes 0.13A In this case, i get 5V on F3001, and 0V on F3000

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: This happens because one port still have one good CC1/2 line.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Shall I remove <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You must replace it.
The board will not work if one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip is missing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: After replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, now, on one port JB500, the meter shows 4.97B and 0.07A and stays powered on steady, and on all other ports, the meter starts for about 3 sec, shows 4.97V and them reboots

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
The steady port still has problem.
Check diode mode on LDO rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I think that are  all normal...

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.515V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.534V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.493V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.529V

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.518V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.527V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.487V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.522V

UB300:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.505V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.533V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.489V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.526V

UB400:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.515V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.532V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.493V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.529V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
JB500 has 2 USB-C ports.
Each port has 2 ways conection possible; 4 possibilities then.
Check which <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> gives the steadtÂ¡y 5V.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I belive that it is the UB300, because with that i have 5V on FB200. 

I think that this one is the problem, because i have 0.150V in diode mode, and only 0.600 k ohm on FB200, while on F3000 i get 2.6 K ohm and 0.191V on diode mode (not sure if it makes sense to you).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Do you get 1V1 LDO on all chips?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
What do you mean? In diode mode all look the same.
Do you mean 1.1V on all ports, with the meter conected?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
The powered <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip should give 1V1 LDO.
Check if all chips do the same.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I don't have 1.1V even on CB404, witch is the corresponding UB400 that works with the meter (5V). I get 0V there. Am I measuring right?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
On UB300 i get the 1.1V
On UB400 i get 1.1V until reboots
On <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> I don't get the 1.1V. I get 0V on both 1.1V LDO lines, but i get 5V on F3000/1

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Be sure to connect charger to corresponding USB-C port.
1V1 LDO appears at only one chip.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I get 1V1 LCO on UB300 (steady), and on UB400 (until reboots meter).
I don't get it on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, witch were the ones  I replaced

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Did you change both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200?
Be sure to get good chips; new from China can be fake.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Yes i changed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and U32000, both new from China.
Is there any way for me to confirm if the chips are ok? When i changed both, the meter went from black to reboot, and now i get 5V on both fuses, and a steady 4.97V on one of the ports (with original <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> UB300).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Too many "new" fake chips from China.
I prefer wing boards they sell after cut off the main logic boards.
You can expect 10-30% of burnt chips.
At least the you can get original chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I have a scrap board here from a 1706 and tomorow i'll reball those <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
Can you send me some link from where you buy those wings?
Tks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I replaced again both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> / <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) for two from a scrap board, but with the same result. The meter is rebooting on 3 ports, and stays steady, at 4.97V, on one of the ports (UB300). All LDO lines are as they were before.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Then UB300 is possibly defective.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi, I've replaced the UB300, and now the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is steady, and all other ports are rebooting the meter...
Do you have any other ideas, or is better to give up on it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
If now power cycles, possibly problem on secondary power supplies.
Check them for short.

Also see what happens in SMC bypass mode.
